The Discovery of the New World by Christopher Columbus in 1492. If I could change this event, I would go back in time and persuade Columbus to take a different route, one that wouldn't have led him to the Caribbean but instead to the Pacific Ocean. This would have prevented the devastating impact of European colonization on the indigenous peoples of the Americas, sparing them from the loss of their cultures, languages, and lives. The alternative route would have also allowed Columbus to discover the Pacific Islands, which could have led to a more peaceful and mutually beneficial exchange between European explorers and the native populations.

The sinking of the Titanic in 1912. I would go back in time and prevent the iceberg from colliding with the ship. This would have saved over 1,500 lives and prevented the tragic loss of some of the most prominent people of the time, including millionaires, politicians, and artists. The sinking of the Titanic also had a profound impact on maritime safety regulations, leading to the implementation of the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea (SOLAS) in 1914. By preventing the disaster, I would have given the world a chance to develop and implement these regulations without the need for such a catastrophic event.

The assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand in 1914. If I could change this event, I would prevent the assassination from occurring. The assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand sparked a chain reaction of events that led to the outbreak of World War I. The war resulted in the loss of millions of lives, widespread destruction, and a profound impact on the global balance of power. By preventing the assassination, I would have given the world a chance to avoid the devastating consequences of the war and potentially prevented the rise of fascist and nationalist ideologies that contributed to World War II.

The fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989. I would go back in time and prevent the fall of the Berlin Wall, but not by stopping the protests and demonstrations that led to its collapse. Instead, I would have the leaders of the Soviet Union and East Germany work together to reform the communist system and create a more open and democratic society. This would have allowed the people of East Germany to experience a peaceful transition to democracy, avoiding the chaos and uncertainty that followed the wall's collapse. Additionally, it would have given the world a chance to see a more gradual and peaceful end to the Cold War.
